section_01.section_summary: Joshua Reynolds was a talented and determined individual who was destined for success in the art world. Born in 1723, he was apprenticed to a portrait painter and later traveled to Italy, where he studied and copied the works of great masters, including Michelangelo and Titian. This experience had a profound impact on his technique and style, and he returned to England as a portrait painter of the first class. Reynolds' time in Italy and his subsequent success were instrumental in establishing the Royal Academy, which he later presided over as its first president. Through his work and teachings, Reynolds left a lasting legacy in the art world, and his paintings continue to be celebrated for their mastery of technique and beauty.

[LOGIC]: abrupt shift between discussing Reynolds' life and criticizing his character
[TRANSITION]: lack of smooth connection between paragraphs
[CLARITY]: some sentences are wordy or ambiguous

section_02.section_summary: Sir Joshua Reynolds quickly gained success as a portrait painter due to the quality of his work and the patronage he received. As his career progressed, he moved to larger studios, raised his prices, and became a prominent figure in society. Reynolds was not only a talented artist, but also a man of the world who enjoyed the company of intellectuals and artists, including Dr. Johnson, Garrick, and Burke. Despite his accomplishments, he had his flaws, including a touch of snobbery, jealousy, and vulgarity, which were somewhat refined through his associations with distinguished people. Overall, Reynolds was a complex and multifaceted individual, and it is interesting to consider both his artistic merits and his personal faults.
